title: Thursday, 30th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hey, hello. Good morning. Welcome.

BE11:03am

Neil H should be joining us shortly, system permitting.

BE11:04am

Quite a bit to talk about, of course, including events in the US overnight.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

(@Neil: you're slumming it over there.)

BE11:05am

We mentioned Juniper a couple of times over the past few weeks, right? Anyway, we'll come back to that.

BE11:05am

Because there are a few things happening domestically as well.

11:06 am
undefined
BE11:07am

So I was going to make today's portrait Paul Dacre, but there are very few on the internet I can use that I have any confidence won't get us a copyright demand.

NH11:07am

Hola. I'm in.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Hooray!

Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT:LSE): Last: 532.00, down 170 (-24.22%), High: 594.00, Low: 500.00, Volume: 1.48m
NH11:07am

ouch

11:07 am
NH11:07am

I know its an illiquid stock but that still a big fall

BE11:08am

Yep, on a mixture of news from DMGT this morning.

BE11:08am

MailOnline's entered profitability! That's something!

11:08 am
NH11:08am

Doesn't appear on my biggest risers/losers FTSE table any more. Not indexed?

BE11:08am

Nope, think it fails on free float rules so not indexed.

NH11:08am

The family of Lord Rothermere

11:08 am
BE11:09am

Which means we often forget to mention it. We forgot to mention, for instance, that it had a decent run into these numbers.

BE11:09am

Which aren't bad. DMG Media 2017 did organic growth of 1%!

BE11:09am

+18% digital ad growth helped counter a 5% decline in print ad revenue.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Unfortunately, we're getting a "transition" year, which is another word for a profit warning.

NH11:09am

I glanced at the top of the results statement and things did look OK

NH11:09am

As ever devil in the detail

11:09 am
NH11:09am

usually page 15 onwards

NH11:10am

(andy - unlikely oil price is still up)

BE11:10am

2017 is fine against bleak expectations. 2018 is not. And it all brings to mind the old football manager joke where a transition period usually means from bad to worse.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

That certainly seems to be the case for DMG Media, which is now on for organic revenue decline next year of mid-single-digits and a 10% margin.

BE11:10am

As in, worst performance for at least half a decade. And that's after at least half a decade of restructuring and fiddling about.

NH11:10am

It's tough in old media land we can atest to that

11:11 am
NH11:11am

does next year's guidance include an ad bounce from a Royal Wedding

NH11:11am

surely that's got to help the Mail

NH11:11am

less so us

11:11 am
NH11:12am

we are a bit curmudgeonly on such things

BE11:12am

Seems guidance includes the Royal Wedding bounce. It also includes the exit of that Hopkins person, which might save a bit on settlements.

NH11:12am

https://www.ft.com...-a303-9060cb1e5f44

11:12 am
NH11:12am

Big cost centre Ms Hopkins

BE11:12am

... though are the payouts for the nonsense that she wrote classed as exceptionals? Anyway ......

BE11:12am

Advertising is completely broken as a business model unless you're a FAANG. See the Buzzfeed news yesterday for evidence of that.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

But that's only part of it.

NH11:13am

100 job cuts wasn't it?

NH11:13am

Quite frightening really.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Yep.

BE11:13am

So back to DMGT, and we also have buried in here a warning on corporate costs running too high. £45m next year, which is about £8m more than expected.

BE11:13am

And a warning on JVs and associate revenue running too low

11:13 am
BE11:13am

And finally, a warning that tax will be more than previously guided.

NH11:14am

the devil was really in the detail

BE11:14am

Indeed. Tax rate now guided to “nearer 18%” next year, which is a percent or two above.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

(Why DMGT only pays mid-teens tax is another fascinating question we won't touch upon right now.)

BE11:14am

On top of that lot we get the sale of US property business EDR and a rejig of sectoral reporting that doesn't really seem to add much in terms of clarity.

NH11:14am

(best not but worthing filing away)

11:14 am
BE11:15am

It's all to deliver "sustainable earnings growth with a strong balance sheet which will underpin DMGT's long-standing commitment to deliver real dividend growth," of course. But investors have been waiting a damn long time for that to happen.

BE11:15am

Here's the excellently named Natasha Brilliant at Citi to summarise where we are.

BE11:15am

DMGT provides detailed guidance for 2018E by division. In the first instance the company describes the coming year as “one of transition” with ongoing challenging conditions in some areas of the business. Specifically within the B2B business the company is targeting low-single digit underlying growth, with the operating margin expected to be in the mid-teens. We currently forecast 5-6% u/l growth, with a 16% margin. The company expects media business to post an underlying rate of decline in the mid-single digits, with a 10% margin (we forecast -2.5% and 11%, respectively). Finally corporate costs are expected to increase to £45m in FY18E (we have £36m currently).

11:15 am
BE11:15am

EDR is one of DMGT’s US commercial property information businesses and is driven by transaction volumes. In light of challenging market conditions and the service nature of EDR, DMGT has started a process to dispose of it. Interestingly the press release offers little commentary around Xceligent, the US property business currently in legal proceedings over an purported data theft from rival CoStar but contrary to recent press releases, it seems that DMGT has no immediate plans for a disposal of this business.

BE11:15am

Post the strategic review, the company has split its businesses into three buckets: 1) operating at scale, 2) focused growth and 3) invest to growth. The segmentation will help drive capital allocation decisions going forward. DMGT has also introduced a Performance Improvement Programme and emphasizes that further disposals could be on the table.

BE11:15am

Those are some weird "business buckets".

11:15 am
NH11:15am

Good name only bettered by Polo Tang of UBS - the analysts with a hole in the middle.

NH11:16am

On the business buckets

NH11:16am

were does traditional print media sit?

11:16 am
NH11:16am

operating at scale I suppose

BE11:16am

Yep. Scale, I think, which seems to be a euphemism for "legacy".

BE11:16am

Jonathan Helliwell at Panmure can add a little colour.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

DMGT is indicating FY18E is likely to be a ‘transitional’ year for EPS: in fact it is arguably the fifth transitional year in a row, and looking particularly ‘transitional’ with an EPS drop of over 20% YOY.

BE11:17am

Despite FY17 results coming in around 5% ahead of our forecast, FY18E guidance looks notably weak across the board, and we expect a significant downgrade to consensus (perhaps nearer to 42p of EPS versus current consensus of 52p). We expect the stock to give back much of its recent rally from low £6s to over £7, as the return to reasonable overall growth (which still looks theoretically valid at some point) gets pushed out yet again.

NH11:17am

Teeth smile

11:17 am
BE11:17am

He's on a hold.

BE11:17am

Logically, the business should return to reasonable LFL growth and stronger margins over time, driven by its fundamentally strong B2B assets. However, as a privately controlled business, the company continues to invest in long term positioning, and the timing of this return to growth remains unclear at this point. With valuation not yet compelling, based on 40p-plus of EPS and c23p of prospective dividend, we remain on the sidelines for now.

NH11:17am

hmmm

11:17 am
BE11:17am

There's also a downgrade from Liberum.

NH11:18am

privately controlled business stands out there

NH11:18am

like Murdoch enterprise

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Yeah, old fashioned media fiefdom.

NH11:18am

public yet private

NH11:18am

and all that entails

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Investors wear a lot of risk and don't get a lot of say, which is tolerable when you're in a growth sector but not in one that's trying to manage structural decline.

BE11:19am

Here's Liberum .....

BE11:19am

[W]e are concerned about the guidance, several aspects of the results and that we have a reshuffle of how the divisions are reported. What is clear is that DMGT faces another year of “transformation” but it is not entirely clear when we will get the acceleration of top-line growth.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

RMS growth looks odd

One oddity in the numbers is that RMS (Risk Insurance system) showed underlying revenue growth of 2% for the FY vs 0% for the 11m, which would suggest double-digit growth in September. That suggests there must have been a much heavier weighting of contracts in September which, given their outlook comments don’t suggest a significant acceleration of underlying revenue growth in 2018E, points to more timing / one-off factors.

BE11:20am

DMGT is guiding to its B2B assets having low-single digit underlying revenue growth (vs +2% in 2017) and a mid-teens operating margin (from 13% in 2017)and its Consumer Media assets having a mid-single digit underlying revenue decline (vs +1% in 2017) and a 10% operating margin (vs 11% in 2017). That suggests the group will have flattish underlying revenue growth vs our expectation pre-today of low single digit growth, with the disappointment being at the Consumer Media side where we had expected revenues to be flat. There may also be some caution on the B2B growth estimates given the lowering of guidance over the years.

The question we would have is, if Mail Online is becoming a greater part of the group (17% of revenues in 2017) and is moving into profits and is faster growth, why is the like for like revenues trend going backwards as well as the margin.

NH11:20am

We should write an algo that triggers sell orders when the word "transformational" is mentioned

11:20 am
NH11:20am

Seems to be the new corporatespeak for profit warning

BE11:21am

Burberry being another recent example, yes.

BE11:21am

Write down of assets suggests the diversification strategy has had several misses

The company has taken £206m in impairment charges against several of its investments including Genscape, Xceligent and SiteCompli due to several issues relating to these assets. That points to the risk of what has been DMGT’s change into an almost-VC style structure where it takes multiple investments.

11:21 am
NH11:21am

This is a litany of bad news

BE11:22am

Yep. And more a "death by a thousand cuts" type than a kitchen sink, if we can lapse into cliche for a moment.

BE11:22am

Management's got its work cut out here.

11:22 am
undefined
NH11:22am

Where now?

NH11:22am

Wider market?

11:22 am
BE11:23am

FTSE not doing much.

NH11:23am

up 15 at pixel time

BE11:23am

Sterling still the main driver, though we have Opec to monkey with things today as well.

11:23 am
NH11:23am

I can opine on Opec

NH11:24am

Half my team in Vienna

NH11:24am

been there for most of the week

11:24 am
NH11:24am

one of the most depressing reporting jobs

NH11:24am

you spend a week chasing Opec ministers around upmarket hotels in Vienna

BE11:24am

Please! The consensus thinks it's "stick" until the end of next year, right?

11:24 am
NH11:24am

who don't want to speak

NH11:24am

and come from countries that don't have a very developed media culture

NH11:25am

it's a real bun fight

11:25 am
NH11:25am

and the wires sends scores of reporters so they can beat each other by 5 seconds to the news

NH11:25am

Anyway

NH11:25am

The day of the meeting is always marked by something call the gangbang

11:25 am
NH11:25am

Which is less interesting than its sounds

BE11:25am

Danger

NH11:26am

What happens is the press turn up to Opec HQ

11:26 am
NH11:26am

which isn't really fit for purpose

NH11:26am

are bundled in a small stair well

NH11:26am

and given 10 minutes at which to fire off questions to ministers

11:26 am
NH11:26am

who are sat behind desks in the main hall

NH11:26am

inevitably there's a scrum around Saudia Arabia

NH11:27am

and Iran

11:27 am
NH11:27am

Anyway it's a massive media scrum

NH11:27am

and a week of doorstepping people who don't want to talk

NH11:28am

as for today's meeting

11:27 am
NH11:28am

here's what Anjli Raval and David Sheppard filled

NH11:28am

post gangbang

NH11:28am

The world’s biggest oil producers are close to extending a deal to curb oil production throughout 2018, Opec ministers said on Thursday, with more work needed to shrink swollen stockpiles and bolster the market. Speaking ahead of a meeting of oil ministers of Opec countries, Russia and other large producers, Saudi Arabia’s energy minister Khalid al Falih said the countries were in “perfect alignment” as they pursue a deal to extend their 1.8m barrel a day cuts throughout 2018. “If something is working you don’t let go,” said Mr Falih.

11:28 am
NH11:28am

His remarks suggest ministers have drawn a line under differences with Russia at odds with other members over the duration of any extension of the deal that came into effect in January. Oil markets have wobbled this week as Russia pushed for a shorter extension to the deal due to concerns over boosting prices too high and reviving US shale. But Opec ministers now appear confident Russia is backing the cuts throughout next year. “Our cooperation with the non-Opec countries will continue to the end of 2018,” Kuwait’s oil minister said Essam al-Marzouq said. Opec’s ministers are holding their own meeting on Wednesday morning before sitting down with Russia and nine other producers this afternoon.

NH11:29am

So we get an extension till end of the year

NH11:29am

unless prices get out of control

11:28 am
NH11:29am

and Russia will push for it to end

NH11:29am

They don't want to lose more market share

NH11:30am

There we have it

11:29 am
NH11:30am

Brent up 1.5% at $64

NH11:30am

really they had no choice but to extend

NH11:30am

anything else would have sparked a sell off

11:30 am
NH11:30am

given positioning is over extended

NH11:31am

Leferve makes a good point on hedgging

NH11:31am

loads happening right now

11:31 am
NH11:31am

n summary:
2017 hedged volumes increased from 1.54 mb/d (50%) to 1.66 mb/d (54%) for a group of 43 producers.
2018 hedged volumes nearly doubled after Q3 17 earnings compared to after H1 17 earnings as producers sought to take advantage of improving oil prices.
The CFTC producer short position has come off its lowest level in almost two years in recent weeks, reflecting the hedging uptick.
The coming months are likely to see a tug of war between higher flat price incentivising hedging vs sustained WTI backwardation deterring some hedging activity.

NH11:31am

That's from Energy Aspects, a very good London-based energy consultancy

BE11:03am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's you know, whatever, this thing.

11:32 am
NH11:32am

so Opec must maintain discipline

BE11:32am

Makes sense.

NH11:32am

otherwise all the hard work will be in vain

11:32 am
NH11:33am

tricky business trying to balance the oil markets

NH11:33am

you want higher prices

NH11:33am

but not so high the US floods the market

11:33 am
NH11:33am

trying to calibrate that is far from easy

NH11:33am

especially when lots of Opec members hate each other

NH11:33am

and no, hate is not too strong a word

11:34 am
NH11:34am

(BHP shale - think it will be a long process. Data room open by end year apparently. Will struggle to find single buyer)

undefined
NH11:34am

Shall we tackle Juniper?

11:34 am
BE11:35am

I guess we need to.

BE11:35am

Regular readers will remember we noted the chat around Juniper here .... https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-11-15/ ..... and also here: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-11-24/

NH11:35am

Yep and the stock exploded higher last night

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Indeed. Things really got going yesterday afternoon. Shares up 5% in a weak market.

BE11:36am

Which is the kind of move that spooks M&A reporters working on a story.

BE11:36am

And, for whatever reason, CNBC pressed the button on a "Nokia in talks to buy Juniper" story.

11:36 am
NH11:36am

Saw that

NH11:36am

which was then 'updated' overnight

BE11:37am

After it brought out a surprisingly strong "ehei" from Nokia.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Nokia is not currently in talks with, nor is it preparing an offer for, Juniper Networks related to an acquisition of that company.

NH11:37am

I'd say that was pretty definitive

BE11:37am

Though "is not currently in talks" is important, of course. We've had a few present-tense denials over the years.

11:37 am
NH11:38am

yes

NH11:38am

telling I would say

BE11:38am

And the gossip around Juniper in recent weeks would perhaps indicate some kind of process going on.

11:38 am
NH11:38am

Yep

NH11:39am

The rumours seems to be they have launched a sale process

NH11:39am

and have been reaching out to potential buyers

11:39 am
NH11:39am

Nokia would be one

NH11:39am

Cisco another

NH11:39am

perhaps others

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Nokia would be one of a quite short list of potential bidders, so would certainly be contacted by such a process (assuming such a process was in train).

NH11:39am

There must be something to this

NH11:40am

the CNBC team are very experienced reporters

11:39 am
NH11:40am

poached from Bloomberg I believe

BE11:40am

McCracken? Yes, he's a good and very experienced reporter who's beaten us to the punch countless times when at Bloomberg.

BE11:40am

Irritatingly.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Anyway, Juniper-Nokia would be market leader in IP routing and would shift the latter towards enterprise, so it makes sense that they'd talk.

NH11:41am

I see

NH11:41am

and Cisco

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Cisco is much more complicated .......

BE11:41am

Here's Raymond James to explain.

BE11:42am

We would have guessed that a private equity (PE) buyer
would have been more likely than a strategic buyer. We believe Juniper has strong FCF at over $1 billion in 2018, and we could imagine a PE buyer valuing Juniper at 12-13x FCF, 15x Net Income or $12-13 billion, which corresponds to $35-37 a share.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

One could argue either that Arista and Cisco benefit from Nokia
facing sales dis-synergies and a less competitive market, or that a more formidable competitor results in a headwind. F5 Networks has been the subject of takeout speculation, and with its healthy FCF, a similar 15x FCF multiple would suggest a value near $12 billion or about $200 a share.

NH11:43am

Interesting

NH11:43am

not an area I'm hugely up to speed on

11:43 am
BE11:44am

One important hurdle here is the Cisco-Ericsson tie-up, Ericsson being The Joker to Nokia's Batman.

BE11:44am

Here's Baird.

BE11:44am

After years of rumors that Cisco would acquire Ericsson,
the two companies announced a strategic partnership in late 2015. At the time, the companies placed a $1 billion revenue target on the partnership, which they are now expecting to miss for 2018. Nevertheless, we believe the Cisco-Ericsson partnership likely put incremental strain on Cisco's relationship with Nokia.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Regulatory issues. CFIUS has taken a hard stance on foreign investment in US technology companies under the new administration. While most recent examples of this have been from Asia-based firms, Finland shares an enormous border with Russia and is non-militarily aligned with NATO. We don't believe regulatory issues would normally be an issue but they could present challenges in the current environment.

NH11:44am

Interesting angle

NH11:45am

sharing a border with Russia

11:45 am
NH11:45am

is enough to make US senators worried

NH11:45am

(Yes. still covering Noble, working on a couple of stories. But the equity story is all played out. Effectively wortheless)

BE11:46am

Yes, feels a wee bit parochial from our perspective but you can imagine some Senator somewhere getting properly excited after checking his World Map wallplanner.

11:45 am
NH11:46am

Cry smile

NH11:46am

I have a couple of bits of RAW

BE11:46am

Excellent! Fire away.

11:46 am
NH11:46am

if the RORT are interested

NH11:46am

one is called Blackhawk Network Holdings

NH11:46am

some sort of prepayment network

11:46 am
NH11:46am

$2bn market so not huge

NH11:47am

and also

NH11:47am

Styles and Wood

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Oh!

Styles and Wood Group PLC (STY:LSE): Last: 346.50, no change, Volume: 0.00
NH11:47am

You know of it

11:47 am
NH11:48am

my knowledge doesn't extend much beyond it being listed in London

BE11:48am

Yeah, property services. Mostly to banks and suchlike.

BE11:49am

Calls itself an environment and project delivery specialist these days I think. Which means office refits.

11:49 am
NH11:49am

I see

BE11:49am

Cheap, arguably. Shore, house broker, says ....

BE11:49am

Styles is trading on a FY2017F PER of 6.5x (EV/EBITDA 3.6x) with a free cash flow yield of 19.8% - moving into a net cash position this year on our current forecasts. For next year FY2018F, the PER falls to 5.8x (EV/EBITDA 2.8x) offering a free cash flow yield of 20.4% - rapidly building up the balance sheet.

11:49 am
NH11:50am

crikey

NH11:50am

big FCF yield

BE11:50am

Against that, loads of uncertainty on public service order book and etc etc.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Anyway, will keep an eye on it.

undefined
NH11:51am

Time for the pub?

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Of course! It's Marston's vs Greene King today.

BE11:52am

And the former is winning.

NH11:52am

ROTR talking about Marston's which doesn't seem to be suffering in the way Mitchells & Butlers from all that cost inflation

11:52 am
Marston's PLC (MARS:LSE): Last: 115.80, up 11 (+10.50%), High: 117.60, Low: 107.00, Volume: 5.09m
Greene King PLC (GNK:LSE): Last: 528.50, down 11.5 (-2.13%), High: 532.50, Low: 495.10, Volume: 2.51m
NH11:53am

Don't have a view on this one

11:53 am
NH11:53am

Not a big beer drinker

BE11:54am

The main difference here is the guidance, which seems somewhat dissonant given both companies sell the same thing to more or less the same people.

BE11:55am

Though it also reflects a different starting point in terms of balance sheet structure etc.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Numis on Greene King to summarise:

BE11:55am

1H17 PBT of £127.9m compares to our forecast £130m, representing an 8% decline y-on-y. Managed pub lfl growth slowed to -2% in the second quarter, although management identifies an improving trend in recent weeks. Weaker than expected lfls and the decision to invest £10m in 'value, service and quality' imply mid single digit downgrades to consensus estimates we believe.

NH11:55am

Nothing 'transformational' there

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Greene King's managed and tenanted, of course, so is quite difficult to analyse. It's effectively two completely independent businesses.

BE11:56am

The managed side has taken a big hit on margins. Down to 16.4%, due to discounting etc.

BE11:57am

While tenanted LFL net income up 1.5%, which is mostly because it's ramping up rents on landlords, who are having to wear the discounts themselves.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Back to Numis.

BE11:58am

The market is likely to focus on securitisation covenants following MAB's recently announced decision not to pay an interim dividend. DSCR in the GNK vehicle was 1.6x on an LTM basis, 1.9x for Spirit. Following the period end, GNK has started to refinance the Spirit debt, taking on a new £350m revolving facility in order to prepay £189m of bonds (with a £43m swap penalty). The effect is to reduce GNK's interest payable by c.£10m pa from FY19.

BE11:58am

GNK's share price has underperformed the market by 21% over the last 3m in response to difficult trading and concerns on the cost outlook. GNK now has the largest managed pub estate in the UK, and remains vulnerable to the twin impacts of wage inflation and a weaker consumer meaning that we remain cautious.

11:58 am
NH11:58am

That financing stuff and the mention of Spirit

NH11:59am

reminds me of the Frankenstein finance stuff

NH11:59am

that used to happen in the pub world with Punch

11:59 am
NH11:59am

and the like

NH11:59am

real bull market stuff

BE12:00pm

True, they were wild times. The tenanted pub operators are a business book example of how not to run a listed company.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Meanwhile, over at Marston's, it's mostly just a relief rally. Numbers are in line and guidance unchanged.

NH12:00pm

I see

NH12:00pm

almost a 10% pop in the share price

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Yup. Holding your forecasts is worth that. Here's Goodbody.

BE12:01pm

Overall, the FY17 performance was as expected, the outlook is unchanged and the group remains committed to the dividend. These factors are likely to lead to these results being well received by the market today in terms of the share price reaction. However, we continue to believe that 2018 will be a difficult year for the sector. With Marston’s higher leverage and weaker cashflow profile it could underperform peers in a tougher environment.

NH12:03pm

RIght, I need to dash. Lunch up West.

12:03 pm
NH12:03pm

Also I won't be able to make ML next week. In Tokyo chairing this

BE12:03pm

(@Pseudonym: the tenanted pub operators rely on a pipeline of people without a lot of business experience who just want to run a pub. And when they fail, there's another one to take over the tenancy, which is why the UK is full of terrible pubs that shouldn't really survive on the numbers they're generating.)

NH12:03pm

https://live.ft.co...ities-Tokyo-Summit

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Cool! That's a good excuse.

NH12:04pm

Never been to Japan

NH12:04pm

so looking forward to it

12:03 pm
NH12:04pm

even if I have to fly BA

NH12:04pm

in one of there 20 year old rust buckets

NH12:04pm

with two inch TV screens

12:04 pm
NH12:04pm

and four old films

NH12:04pm

all for a premium price

NH12:05pm

excellent business model BA has on long haul

12:06 pm
NH12:06pm

(Pseudonym - don't own a tablet. Just a Kindle)

BE12:06pm

Can't wait for Ryanair or whoever to disrupt the long-haul market. It'll happen eventually.

NH12:06pm

They could just copy BA

12:06 pm
NH12:06pm

and cut the ticket price

NH12:07pm

Right I'm off

NH12:07pm

See ya

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Thanks for joining, Neil.

BE12:07pm

Thanks for joining, Rabble.

BE12:08pm

Thanks everyone. Happy Thursday, and good afternoon all.

11:31 am
NH11:32am

In other words there will be lots of US shale coming to market next year
